title: Motion of orbiting satellite - energy two points

content.question: A satellite has speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> when it is at point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, which is located outside Earth’s atmosphere a distance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> from Earth’s center. The satellite then fires its thrusters and eventually reaches point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>, a distance <math alttext="5 R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mi>R</mi></math> from Earth’s center, where the satellite again has speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math>. The total mechanical energy of the satellite-Earth system is <math alttext="E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></msub></math> when the satellite is at point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, and <math alttext="E sub Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></msub></math> when the satellite is at point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>. Which of the following correctly compares <math alttext="E sub Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Q</mtext></msub></math> to <math alttext="E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math>, and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: <math alttext="E sub Q equals E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Q</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math>, because the thruster exerts a force equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the gravitational force exerted by Earth.

<math alttext="E sub Q equals E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Q</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math>, because the satellite has the same kinetic energy at both points.

<math alttext="E sub Q is greater than E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Q</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math>, because the gravitational potential energy increases with increasing distance from Earth’s center.

<math alttext="E sub Q is greater than E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Q</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math>, because the total mechanical energy of the system is proportional to the distance between the satellite and Earth’s center.

content.answer: <math alttext="E sub Q is greater than E sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Q</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math>, because the gravitational potential energy increases with increasing distance from Earth’s center.
